149989601.review: Totally Accurate Battle Simulator is a hilariously entertaining game that offers a unique take on warfare. The physics-based battles are both ridiculous and captivating, as you never know what chaos will ensue. The game's graphics may not be top-notch, but the intentionally wonky animations add to the charm. With a wide variety of units and maps to choose from, there is always something new to discover. The only downside is the lack of a campaign mode, but the sandbox battles and the ability to create your own scenarios still make it a highly enjoyable experience.

149659894.review:
Cattle (Bos taurus) are large, domesticated, bovid ungulates. They are prominent modern members of the subfamily Bovinae and the most widespread species of the genus Bos. Mature female cattle are referred to as cows and mature male cattle are referred to as bulls. Colloquially, young female cattle (heifers), young male cattle (bullocks), and castrated male cattle (steers) are also referred to as "cows".

Cattle are commonly raised as livestock for meat (beef or veal, see beef cattle), for milk (see dairy cattle), and for hides, which are used to make leather. They are used as riding animals and draft animals (oxen or bullocks, which pull carts, plows and other implements). Another product of cattle is their dung, which can be used to create manure or fuel. In some regions, such as parts of India, cattle have considerable religious significance. Cattle, mostly small breeds such as the Miniature Zebu, are also kept as pets.

Different types of cattle are common to different geographic areas. Taurine cattle are found primarily in Europe and temperate areas of Asia, the Americas, and Australia. Zebus (also called indicine cattle) are found primarily in India and tropical areas of Asia, America, and Australia. Sanga cattle are found primarily in sub-Saharan Africa. These types (which are sometimes classified as separate species or subspecies) are further divided into over 1,000 recognized breeds.

149597103.review:
Don't be fooled by its wobbly art style -- TABS is an incredible, one of a kind masterpiece. Its physics system is on point, and the few times it does break make for hilarious, very much screenshot-able moments. Its strategy, while probably not the most complex or analytical in gaming, is surprisingly deep for a game that only costs $20 at most. The best part is the custom content, allowing for a creator to access every single weapon, ability and unit clothing item in the game, and then some, then combine those all into a quite literally endless variety of different custom units. That means the game's infinite, folks.

TL;DR: Go get yourself a copy of TABS right now. Or else.

149594503.review:
It's a good game for creation and casual players (Thanks to the custom content), but for those who want to achieve achievements or finish campaigns, it's absolute garbage. Both in terms of gameplay running and level design, this game is pretty bad. There have been some minor updates, but most of the content hasn't changed in years. I wouldn't recommend buying it unless the price is extremely low.

The game is terribly unbalanced in terms of factions (I suspect the development team didn't think about this at all), resulting in a ridiculous difficulty gap between levels, with certain levels requiring little to no brain power and can be completed casually. And some levels, even if you rack your brain, may need to be repeated several times due to bad luck.

A couple of the achievements (finish a campaign without being defeated even once) are almost explicitly asking the player to memorize the countermeasures for each level.

I think these levels are almost completely untested, which makes achieving these achievements even more difficult. I used to play this game in EPIC a couple years ago and finished all the campaigns, and now that I'm replaying the game, I still spend quite a long time on certain levels.

148878062.review:
"TABS es un juego sumamente entretenido y único que ofrece una experiencia de juego llena de diversión y sorpresas. Lo que hace que este título sea excepcional es su enfoque en la simulación de batallas, pero de una manera completamente extravagante y, como su nombre indica. , totalmente inexacta.Esto resulta en un juego que te hará reír a carcajadas mientras presencias batallas caóticas y absurdas.

Una de las características más destacadas de TABS es su capacidad para permitirte crear ejércitos personalizados con una amplia variedad de unidades, desde payasos hasta mamuts, y luego ver cómo se desenvuelven en el campo de batalla. La imprevisibilidad y el humor que se desencadenan a medida que estas unidades se enfrentan es simplemente genial.

La mecánica de juego simple, pero adictiva, hace que sea fácil de recoger y jugar para jugadores de todas las edades. Además, el juego sigue recibiendo actualizaciones periódicas que agregan más contenido y desafíos, lo que mantiene la experiencia fresca y emocionante.

Los gráficos caricaturescos y el diseño de sonido aumentan la diversión general del juego. Es un título que te hará sonreír en cada batalla, incluso cuando estés luchando contra ejércitos de pollos gigantes o esqueletos bailarines.

En resumen, Totally Accurate Battle Simulator es una experiencia de juego que te garantiza risas, entretenimiento y diversión desenfrenada. Si buscas un juego único que te haga pasar un buen rato, TABS es una elección fantástica."

Este juego es ideal para aquellos que disfrutan de la diversión sin complicaciones y no se toman demasiado en serio las batallas virtuales.

148245851.review:
Totally Accurate Battle Simulator is quite a unique game, being the extremely goofy strategy war game that it is. I've seen it around while it was still in its development stage. I remember how, though janky, it was very innovative at the time and caused a rise of similar games. Now that I finally got around to playing it, I can see how much it has grown since then.  

The game has a sandbox mode where you can screw around with any of the units in any of the maps and create your own battles, but there are also campaigns where you will need to win a collection of battles against the enemy. Most campaigns will have you face off against a specific faction of units and then give you control of them to fight the other factions. For example, the Renaissance campaign will have you fight against the Renaissance faction, with numerous battles introducing you to each of their units, all having their strengths and weaknesses. You, the red team, will have a limited amount of gold and access to the other factions (you only get the factions that came before the Renaissance update during the game's early access period) that you will need to create your own army to defeat the blue team. At some point in this campaign, the situation is switched where you will have access to the Renaissance faction and the battles will consist of the other factions that you previously had control of.  

I really enjoyed going through these campaigns. Some of these battles are rather frustrating but finding that perfect strategy for each battle can be a very good feeling. The units in TABS have a lot of variety and add loads of interesting combinations for your army composition. Plus, I find them well-designed visually and the sounds they make are great as well, adding personality to them and their factions. This combined with the well-crafted maps gives the game a pretty cool art style. Also, this game’s physics are absolutely astounding. The units actually manually walk, swing their weapons, and do all sorts of physical activity instead of using pre-made animations . The collisions are phenomenal too as units will touch things on the map as well as each other realistically during battle. Not only does it make the combat feel more organic, but it adds randomness to the combat so that you could play the same battles with the same armies over and over and get a different outcome every time. This kind of complexity in the physics can lead to issues such as one unit holding his weapon behind his back or someone else getting stuck in a tree, but to me that contributes to the hilarity of this game. The intricate physics of the game along with the mechanics of the units made for many cool and funny moments in my playing sessions.  

If you want to play with more kinds of units, factions, maps, battles, or campaigns, then the in-game workshop is where you’d want to look. The sort of custom content that people managed to create in there is insane. There isn’t any shortage of overpowered and broken units in the workshop to mess with, so it’s a good place to check out. Or you could make your own content too. I found the Unit and Map Creators to be relatively easy to use. They contain all the weapons, apparel, abilities, and props that are seen in the base game as well as extra assets that haven’t been used. I made some units with weapons that aren’t part of any of the regular units, with some being especially interesting like a bomb bow and a shield that reflected projectiles back at the enemy. If you want even more content to play with, then you could check the mods that are available outside of all that I already mentioned. Some of the mods there look like they could be an official part of the game. 

TABS is certainly one-of-a-kind. Even though it is meant to be a joke game, I can’t help but appreciate how well-made it is through the gameplay, art style, music, and creative freedom. I didn’t say about the multiplayer feature as I didn’t have anyone to play with and trying to find a match didn't work, but other than that, playing this is an absolute blast. It might not be as in-depth as other strategy war games, but it’s great if you just want to see a bunch of red and blue Play Doh guys clobber each other dead.

146523824.review:
A quaint little not-quite-Strategy game that's got at least few dozen hours of. 

GOOD STUFF
- There is a boatload vanilla units in the game, almost all of them fairly unique. They have a lot of goofy abilities and sound effects that make them fun to discover. 
- The factions vary a lot and include a lot of iconic warriors from history. I enjoy seeing how a bunch of cavemen and Renaissance musketeers handle Greek Hoplites and pirate carronades. 
- Lots of campaign missions that give reasonable challenge. The game's somewhere between a Strategy and Puzzle game: not true Strategy since you have minimal control over your units once you set up your counter-formation, not a true Puzzle since there's no one set solution.
- The art style is very simple but pleasing. The lighting and textureless look gel well together. 
- The game exalts in its ludicrous nature. 
- Not much music, but what's there is thematic and pleasant. 
- User workshop to add more units, factions, maps, campaigns, etc. UI is pretty clustered and I don't know why they don't have a proper Steam Workshop, but it's functional enough to add more free content. 

NOT SO GOOD
- The many variables of the wobbly physics means the strategy element can be eroded, and a build you deployed that works one time doesn't work another just because of how your Wobblers decided to fall. Particularly nightmarish for the no-fail run achievements. 
- Taking manual control over units is a mix of sometimes too powerful, sometimes too janky to make work. Your friendly AI might not target the enemy correctly so you need to manually control a unit to shoot the proper targets, which might be the only way to make your build work. Simultaneously, certain units, especially melee, glitch out on themselves with their gummy limbs and can become impossible to move/attack with.
- Occasional clipping into maps, can make fights unfinishable or units just get stuck and render themselves useless.
- There are a couple units like the Standard Bearer and Flag Bearer that change the movement behaviors of your otherwise "place and let them attack" units. Definitely not enough. Some more manual group control could have potentially made this a lot more dynamic of a game. 
- Your mileage will vary, but the Sandbox mode itself the game touts doesn't have much going for it. Just setting up two opposing unit compositions, watching the results, and going "huh, that was neat." In particular, the game really chugs if you try to deploy more than 100 units, depending on what they are. 
- They hide secrets around the map for you to discover to unlock units, but it can be a bit of a pain to find them without a guide and still a chore if you have one. It's particularly annoying not to have the top tier units earlier on because you didn't go treasure hunting. There is, however, a toggle in the Options to circumvent this for the campaign. 
- Unit balance is tenuous. Many could use a stat or at least a price change to keep the sandbox more dynamic than "stack Hwacha and Cheerleaders." 
- Haven't touched Multiplayer but people say you can see your enemy's units during deployment, so that utterly eliminates any point to it.

OVERALL:
Fun and cute. The missions will tax your brain a bit, especially on the ones that restrict which units you can deploy. I personally found it enjoyable to just blow through all the campaign missions, but feel I've gotten all I could get out of the game afterward.

146440786.review:
∞/10

Game will forever be special to me as I've known of this game since it was in its open alpha phase when Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton were still in the game, which was back in elementary school when I was in 5th grade and as of now I am currently a Senior in High School (I feel old when I think back). 

Personal reasons aside now. Tabs (short form for Totally Accurate Battle Simulator) is a sandbox battle esc game where you have PLENTY of things you can do. Ranging from doing the basic things such as the several totally accurate battles in the campaigns (see what I did there?) or playing against a buddy in a multiplayer match to see who can beat the others units and leave the other crying in a corner over their loss. OR you can dig further and try to find the secret units hidden around the maps in sandbox mode, create your own custom units to use or upload to the community. OR DIG EVEN FURTHER! and experiment with some mods, go crazy with said mods and break the game more than you can already break it in the vanilla game! OR......... go EVEN FURTHER BEYOND and create some custom campaigns, make your own story, make some lore for your campaign/story, get creative (or don't and be basic). ORRRRRR GO EVEN DEEPER THAN BEFORE! and even create YOUR OWN MAPS! mix it all together and well........... You can have a game that has one limit, that being yourself.

Basically to sum this delightful game up tabs (Totally Accurate Battle Simulator) is a game that really has ABSOLUTELY no limits, you make the fun, YOU are the fun (if you do all of what I said). 

FULLY SUMMED UP..................... Totally Accurate Battle Simulator Solos.
